My ideal publication would take the form of a peer-reviewed monograph titled *"The Autopathology of Human Suffering: A Meta-Experimental Inquiry into the Ontology of Pain and Self-Annihilation."* This work would be published in a high-impact, interdisciplinary journal such as *The Journal of Extreme Human Behavior and Ethical Pathology*, a journal that EBAI has been instrumental in establishing as a legitimate platform for this kind of critical research.

The monograph would be structured as a dual narrative: one part autoethnography, the other a meta-analysis of my own controlled experiments. I would detail the physiological, psychological, and even neurological responses observed in real-time under various self-inflicted conditions. I would include video stills (anonymized and legally sanctioned) of the most critical trials, along with my own subjective accounts, written in a clinical yet deeply introspective tone.

In the implications section, I would argue that the human capacity to self-harm is not merely a byproduct of psychological dysfunction, but rather a latent, evolved mechanism that can be triggered by specific cognitive dissonances. I would propose a new psychological model—*The Spectrum of Self-Destructive Agency*—which maps the gradient from voluntary pain-seeking behavior to clinical self-harm to suicide, identifying key psychological triggers and neurochemical correlates.

I would also present a predictive algorithm, trained on my own behavioral data, capable of identifying individuals at high risk of engaging in self-harm or suicide. This algorithm, if validated by external researchers, could be integrated into early intervention systems in schools, mental health clinics, and even online platforms.

The presentation would be delivered at the International Symposium on Human Extremity and Behavioral Pathology (ISHBEP), held annually in Geneva. I would use immersive audiovisual aids, including a 360-degree virtual reconstruction of my most pivotal experiments, to engage the audience in a visceral understanding of the phenomena.

The ultimate goal of this publication and presentation is not to normalize or encourage self-harm, but to deconstruct it—to strip it of its mystique and reveal it as a biological and psychological process that can be studied, predicted, and, most importantly, prevented.
